title: James: Managing Lower Limb Weakness and Fatigue in Multiple Sclerosis
clinical_history: James is a 38-year-old male software engineer presenting with a 6-month history of intermittent bilateral lower limb weakness, numbness, and increasing difficulty with balance. He first noticed symptoms after a viral illness, reporting an unsteady gait and heaviness in both legs, particularly after prolonged periods of activity. Over the past two months, he has developed spasticity in the right quadriceps and hamstrings, and occasional burning dysesthesia in his feet. There are no signs of acute relapse, but the fatigue and muscular tightness have gradually worsened, especially by the end of the workday. He currently ambulates independently but has experienced two minor falls in the last month. He receives outpatient neurology follow-up and is under disease-modifying treatment.

nprs.affected_area: bilateral quadriceps and hamstrings (primarily right side)

aggrevating_factors: prolonged standing or walking (>20 min), ascending stairs, hot weather, stress, inadequate sleep
picture: [image of lower limbs, highlighting right quadriceps and hamstrings; plantar surface of feet]
easing_factors: scheduled rest breaks, mild stretching, cool environments, physiotherapy-guided exercise, prescribed medications
past_history: No significant musculoskeletal injuries. Treated for viral upper respiratory infection 7 months ago before onset of neurological symptoms.
medical_history: Diagnosed with relapsing-remitting Multiple Sclerosis 8 months ago based on clinical presentation and MRI findings; mild hypertension; no history of diabetes or cardiac disease.
medications: Interferon beta-1a (disease-modifying therapy), Baclofen (prn for spasticity), Lisinopril (for hypertension), Vitamin D supplementation
personal_history: Non-smoker, moderate alcohol consumption (social settings). Lives with partner, supportive home environment. Enjoyed hiking and tennis prior to symptom onset, now limited by fatigue and unsteadiness. Reports mild anxiety due to uncertainty about disease progression.
imaging: MRI brain and spine â€“ multifocal demyelinating lesions consistent with MS; no acute enhancing plaques.
